text: from the air Chiapas Mexico's
southernmost state is a gorgeous quilt
of Hills rivers and lakes but that's no
way to see the rainforests Mayan ruins
and Indian villages of one of Mexico's
most isolated regions I'm Matt gross a
frugal traveler for the New York Times
and when I explored Chiapas over 10 days
this fall I traveled almost solely by
colectivo colectivos our shared minivans
and they form a network of travel routes
that let you roam all over the state
cheaply it can be a bumpy ride and
occasionally crowded but it's often the
only way to get from place to place my
first stop was Xena on an Indian
village with a magnificent church and a
number of young women who will lead you
to their families textile workshops when
is done you can take photos if you want
to each village has its own style and
Xena Canton is famous for its embroidery
but it was a scarf that was my first
priority this one cc Chiapas despite
being officially in the tropics actually
gets quite cold at night especially in
the mountains the prices however were
low like the temperature this scarf was
just 50 pesos for about four dollars six
hours in another colectivo brought me to
palenque the ruins of an ancient mayan
city oh yeah the mines lived here for
1,000 years and I heard a Spanish
speaking guide it was 200 pesos versus
up to 800 or 850 for an english-speaking
one Palenque used to be a major city in
the region home to one of the greatest
Kings mccauley I don't great he was an
incredible one I then pin sign the
collar I got a holy city this may have
been but it's increasingly
commercialized now with vendors allowed
to operate within the protected site
the next day it was back on the bus my
destination the rain forest near the
Guatemalan border it was an occasionally
nerve-racking journey not just because
of the road but also because of the many
military checkpoints even after 15 years
the government is still hunting
zapatista rebels in these hills and
jungles hey come nap number flaws in
order to walk for about two hours and we
are also going to see the plants and
animals and places that are very hilly
not very flat no kidding but apart from
a little mud it wasn't too challenging a
hike
you
